Petroleum Institute (API) Inspection Codes, CCR Petroleum Safety Orders, and company Inspection Best Practices. 

Improvements in technology provide another opportunity to enhance facility safety. Inherently Safer Systems are actively studied as a part of all new project implementation work. Improving safety at RREC is an ongoing activity.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The Phillips 66 Company (Phillips 66) Rodeo Renewable Energy Complex facility (RREC or facility) is located in unincorporated Contra Costa County, near the town of Rodeo, California. The RREC encompasses a total of 1,100 acres of land, consisting of the 495-acre active area of the property, where all its facilities and equipment are located, and another 600 acres of undeveloped areas. The RREC previously operated as a refinery (San Francisco Refinery at Rodeo [SFR]) until modifications and renovations at the facility converted the facility to renewable fuels production in the 3rd quarter of 2024. The facilitys principal activity is renewable fuels manufacturing, wherein the facility converts renewable feedstock (soybean oil, tallow, distillers corn oil, canola oil, used cooking oil) into renewable diesel and jet fuel products, and renewable butane and naphtha for own use. The RREC consists of the renewable fuels manufacturing facility processes and support units that produce industrial fuels and sulfur. In addition, the facility blends procured gasoline blend-stocks into gasoline. Numerous chemicals, materials, and utilities are required to produce useful products from the renewable feedstock.

The RREC is subject to RMP program requirements because it stores and uses regulated substances in quantities exceeding the State-regulated thresholds. The facility contains flammables, hydrogen sulfide (H2S), and aqueous ammonia (NH3) in quantities that exceed their respective state RMP thresholds. Hydrogen sulfide quantities do not exceed federal RMP thresholds in the facilitys processes. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The RRECs Commitment to Responsible Business Policy best depicts the mission and vision set forth for the facility. The Policy emphasizes the commitment to operate and maintain the facility and equipment in a manner that promotes (1) the health, safety, and security of employees, neighbors, and the pub

lic and (2) the responsible use of resources and care of the environment. The facilitys mission statement also includes a safe work environment for employees.

The RREC has a policy advocating a safe workplace and sound environmental operations. Phillips 66 places primary responsibility for health, safety, and the environment within each of the major facilities. Each major facility has comprehensive programs and policies for addressing these areas. The Health, Safety and Environmental Policy established by the corporation is included in its entirety below:

Phillips 66 is committed to the safety of everyone who works in our facilities, lives in the communities where we operate or uses our products. We will conduct our business with care for the environment. We strive for world class operating excellence by integrating our Health, Occupational Safety, Process Safety and Environmental principles throughout our businesses with a commitment to continuous improvement.

Our Action Plan:
¿ Comply with all applicable laws and regulations
¿ Attain incident free operations through systematic risk identification and mitigation
¿ Use resources efficiently and minimize environmental impact
¿ Ensure a safe, healthy and secure work place
¿ Provide our employees and contractors with the knowledge and capability to achieve HSE excellence including empowering them to stop work they believe is unsafe
¿ Set operational and compliance objectives and be accountable for our performance
¿ Communicate our principles and results to employees, contractors, regulators, communities and other stakeholders

The Release Prevention Program Elements are a part of the overall safety program at the facility. The RREC uses a Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) Management System (HSEMS) to coordinate the programs as required by the Phillips 66 corporate standard. The objective of the RREC HSEMS is to ensure that business activities are conducted in a safe and environmentally responsible manner throu

gh the implementation of the HSE policies and the Phillips 66 HSEMS Standard. This objective is achieved by providing organizational structure, programs, procedures, processes, and resources to manage the business activities safely and with respect and care for the environment. The HSEMS seeks to:
¿ Demonstrate management commitment to health, safety, and environmental stewardship.
¿ Ensure that all reasonably practicable steps are taken to identify the hazards and risks arising from our business activities.
¿ Establish adequate control over business activities with the aim of achieving safe, incident- and injury-free working conditions.
¿ Maximize operational integrity, reliability, and efficiency.
¿ Ensure regulatory compliance.
¿ Promote high standards and the continuous improvement of our HSE performance.

The HSEMS system is described in the RREC HSEMS Program Description document available to all employees via the company intranet (Connect66). The document provides a description of the programs, procedures, and processes that are in place at RREC to implement the Phillips 66 Company and RRECs HSE policies. The corporate HSEMS Standard describes a five-phase continuous improvement cycle of Policy and Leadership, Plan, Do, Assess, and Adjust built around 15 management system elements. Each management system element is assigned to an Element Owner, who has the responsibility for its implementation. Senior Management has the overall responsibility for the HSEMS. Many of the elements, such as Asset & Operations Integrity, mirror elements of the RMP. The Process Safety Management Program & HSE Management System Element Cross-Reference, describes how the RMP program elements fit into the HSEMS.

The Element Owner conducts an annual evaluation following the HSEMS Excellence Assessment Process model to assess performance levels and identify areas for improvement. Each Element Owner, working with a team of employees, develops annual improvement goals. Goals are based o

n the HSEMS Standard, the annual review, audit findings, employee suggestions, incident statistics, leading metrics, incident investigations, best practices, and other sources. The HSE Manager and the Refinery Leadership Team develop strategic HSE goals for inclusion in the annual Business Planning process.

The RMP prevention program elements are assigned Element Owners as follows:
¿ The General Manager is responsible for the Management System and Employee Participation program elements.
¿ The Process Safety Specialist is responsible for Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Management of Change (MOC) and Pre Start-Up Safety Review (PSSR) program elements.
¿ The Process Safety Director is responsible for the Compliance Audits.
¿ Personnel in the Health and Safety Department have responsibility for Hot Work, Contractors, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Planning and Response.
¿ Training for Operators and Operating Procedures are the responsibility of the Operations Training Supervisor.
¿ Training for maintenance employees is the responsibility of the Maintenance Department.
¿ Mechanical Integrity is jointly owned between Technical Services and Maintenance Departments.

The RRECs Policies and Procedures Manual contains the policies pertaining to safety and environmental performance and is available to employees on the RRECs intranet. Senior Management is ultimately responsible for the Policies and Procedures Manual. The manual contains Emergency Response Policies, which establish a management standard for reporting emergencies, response to emergencies, and individual employee actions during emergencies.

FACILITY OVERVIEW AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Phillips 66 RREC is located in unincorporated Contra Costa County, near the town of Rodeo. The facility encompasses a total of 1,100 acres of land, consisting of the 495-acre active area of the facility, where all its facilities and equipment are located, and another 600 acres of undeveloped areas. It is bordere

d by the NuStar Terminal to the north, and an undeveloped area to the east. To the south is a 300- to 600-foot undeveloped area (property maintained as buffer areas between the active or developed portion of the facility and adjacent land uses), beyond which is the Bayo Vista residential area. San Pablo Bay borders the facility to the west.

Interstate Highway 80 and San Pablo Avenue run north-south through the RREC property. The property is zoned as heavy industrial. Land uses to the northeast of the facility are a combination of industrial and open space. To the east is primarily open space, and a combination of residential, light commercial, and light industrial uses are found to the south and southwest. The nearest sensitive receptor is a day-care facility in the Bayo Vista residential area, near the southern property boundary, south of the undeveloped buffer zone.

The facilitys principal activity consists of renewable fuels manufacturing processes. Support units produce other industrial fuels and sulfur. RREC processes approximately 50,000 barrels per day (BPD) (one barrel equals 42 gallons) of renewable feedstocks (e.g., soybean oil, tallow, distillers corn oil, canola oil, used cooking oil) into renewable fuel products. The principal fuels produced are renewable diesel and renewable jet fuels. The facility also produces renewable butane and renewable naphtha for own use and elemental sulfur for commercial purposes. In addition, the facility receives procured gasoline blend-stocks via the facilitys Marine Terminal and blends them to produce gasoline.

Tallow/grease and low and high pour point oils are brought to the facility by rail and the facilitys Marine Terminal, located at the northwestern edge of the facility. Numerous chemicals, materials, and utilities are required to produce useful products from the renewable feedstocks. Some chemicals, such as hydrogen, are produced at the RREC or supplied by Air Liquide, which operates the hydrogen Production P

lant adjacent to the facility. Other feedstock, chemicals, and materials are purchased and transported to the facility. The facility generates its own steam, fuel gas, and electricity, and purchases other resources, such as natural gas and water.

The facility accomplishes the production of these products from renewable feedstocks through the use of many complex processing units. Since converting to the RREC, many of the former refinerys process units  have ceased operation. The following discussion describes the RRECs existing processes.

Renewable feedstocks are first sent to pretreatment units to remove impurities before processing. Two pretreatment trains are used to decontaminate and condition the feed prior to hydro-processing. A standard degumming and bleaching process configuration utilized in the renewables industry is used for each train, with the addition of a polyethylene removal section in one train, specifically for tallow feed. A fats, oils, and greases recovery unit that consists of tanks, vessels, centrifuges, and evaporators is used to remove organic material from process wastewater before treatment at the existing facility wastewater treatment plant.

RREC modified both Hydrotreater Units to make them capable of processing treated renewable feed. These units treat the hydrocarbon molecules by breaking them into smaller molecules in the presence of hydrogen and a catalyst. Unsaturated compounds are saturated during this hydrotreating process in addition to breaking larger chain or ringed hydrocarbons into smaller compounds. The hydrotreater process creates small hydrocarbons as well as the larger factions described above. The renewable butanes produced by the hydrotreating process are used in the facility as fuel and as feed for the RREC Hydrogen Plant.

The diesel hydrotreating unit removes nitrogen from the feedstock and sulfur from the chemical agent used to sulfide the catalyst, creating ammonia and hydrogen sulfide, which are processed elsew

here. This unit also saturates unsaturated compounds. Units like the diesel hydrotreating unit separate these small molecules. The smallest molecules (one, two, and three carbons) are sent to the Fuel Gas Center for subsequent use in the facility as fuel. Renewable butanes are produced for own use within the facility.

The facility has a Steam Power Plant that produces electricity as well as high pressure, high temperature steam, which is used for both heating and cooling various processes. The Steam Power Plants demineralizer produces high quality water for use in the plant and process cooling systems. The Waste Water Treatment Plant is the facilitys waste water treatment system. The water that is removed from feedstock prior to processing and water from other process stages, including stripped sour water, is treated by biological systems and carbon filtration prior to its permitted discharge.

The sulfur and nitrogen removed from processing streams is sent to the Sulfur Complex consisting of two units. Unit 237 is a new unit for the RREC. The first unit was modified to process acid gas streams from the facility amine regenerators. The second unit is new for the RREC and is used to destroy ammonia while minimizing formation of nitrogen oxides. The Sulfur Complex converts the sulfur in the streams (as hydrogen sulfide) into elemental sulfur. The elemental sulfur is sold to agricultural markets.

Blending and Shipping is a separate gasoline blending train that includes tankage for gasoline blend-stocks and blending  as well as storage of the finished gasoline. This process also includes one pressurized storage vessel that stores renewable butane produced by the hydrotreaters for use in the facility as fuel and as feed for the Hydrogen Plant Unit 110.

Description of Regulated Substances

Many of the substances handled at the facility regulated by the RMP program are flammables. These materials range in flammability from pentane (with a flash point greater than -40

°F) to hydrogen (with a flash point of -100 °F). Higher flash points indicate less flammability. Materials with low flash points must be handled carefully and isolated from ignition sources to prevent fires or explosions. Regulated flammables are primarily gases at normal pressure and temperature or materials that vaporize very quickly.

As part of processing renewable feedstock to produce renewable fuels, some regulated toxic substances are generated in addition to the flammables. Hydrogen sulfide and aqueous ammonia are present at the facility at quantities exceeding their state regulatory limits; however, only aqueous ammonia exceeds the federal RMP regulatory limits. Hydrogen sulfide and ammonia are hazardous principally through inhalation.

Hydrogen sulfide (H2S), with its characteristic rotten egg odor, is created in the processing units that remove sulfur and nitrogen from the process streams. In addition, some hydrogen sulfide is generated from the catalyst sulfiding agent used in certain processes. It is a colorless, corrosive, toxic gas and its odor can be readily detected at concentrations below concern. Hydrogen sulfide is not stored at the facility. As soon as it is generated, it is immediately sent to the Sulfur Complex for processing. In addition, minor amounts of hydrogen sulfide may evolve from spills of sour water.

Ammonia is also created and treated by the same processing units. Ammonia is a colorless, corrosive, toxic gas with a sharp irritating odor. Its odor is also readily detectable at concentrations below concern. The facility uses aqueous ammonia to regenerate or prepare new catalyst and for nitrogen oxide emission control. 

There are several other regulated substances present at the facility at quantities below their regulatory thresholds, and thus not subject to RMP requirements.

No other substances at the facility are included in the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Title 40, Part

68, Tables 1 and 2.

The maximum inventories of applicable RMP chemicals stored at the RREC are provided per 40 CFR 68.115. Only streams containing one percent or greater of a regulated toxic or flammable materials are included in the reported maximum inventories. Toxic mixtures with a partial pressure of the regulated substance below 10 millimeters of mercury are not included in the inventories. For toxic mixtures, only the weight of the regulated substance is reported. For flammable mixtures, the entire weight of the mixture is treated as the regulated substance, per 40 CFR 68.115(b)(2). Flammable mixtures that do not have a National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) flammability hazard rating of 4 are not covered under RMP.

Covered Processes

This RMP divides the facility into six processes. For processes that exceed the maximum intended inventory thresholds for regulated substances, the RMP defines three program levels, each with its own requirements. The applicable program level is dependent upon the complexity, accident history, and potential impact of releases of regulated substances. The RREC has only Program Level 3 processes. The covered processes for the RREC are:

PROGRAM LEVEL 3:
¿ Steam Power Plant
¿ Fuel Gas Center
¿ Diesel Hydrotreater
¿ Blending and Shipping
¿ Two Hydrotreater Processes

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

The Chemical Safety Information, Site Security and Fuels Regulatory Relief Act restricts the distribution of offsite consequence analysis (OCA) information for security purposes. For this reason, the OCA for the RREC is not included here.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM/POLICIES AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The RMP for the hazardous substances regulated by federal RMP regulations have been developed and implemented to enhance employee and public safety.

Management Systems

The RREC has implemented a management system for developing and continually improving the RMP elements. The General Manager has the over

facility design, locked valves, proper design of pipe bracing and vent locations, freeze protection, proper pipe rating, emergency block valves, and excess flow valves;
¿ Instrument failure: periodic testing of critical safety devices, including pressure safety valves.

Many of the safeguards mentioned above are automatic safety systems that are commonly referred to as interlocks. In addition, the refinery has a flare system that will safely burn vented materials from the process units.

While the emphasis is on prevention of potential hazards, the facility also implements a number of mitigation measures in the event a release should occur. The RREC recognizes that early detection is an important part of managing a release. An example of a detection safeguard would be that process and storage areas have leak detection systems for hydrocarbons, hydrogen sulfide, and ammonia. In addition, the facility has perimeter monitors for hydrogen sulfide and sulfur dioxide as well as a fence-line monitoring system. Mitigation is also an important part of managing an accidental release. 

As part of safeguarding against escalation of an event, the facility has a comprehensive Emergency Response Program.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The RMP regulation requires a listing of accidents for the past 5 years from covered processes that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. The RREC has not had an accident involving a covered process that met these criteria in the last 5 years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The emergency response program is described in a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP), which consists of organization, procedures, and equipment for an emergency response. This program addresses emergency responses for fires, explosions, releases of hazardous materials and medical emergencies. The ERP addresses coordination with local ag

encies and the public.

The ERP has been prepared in coordination with the local emergency response area plan (the Contra Costa County Hazardous Materials Area Plan). In addition, the ERP contains a number of annexes, including the RREC Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan and the Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasures Plan.

The ERP is an important resource tool that includes sections on the Incident Command System, roles and responsibilities, alarm and notification systems, response procedures for specific emergencies, internal and external resources, training and drill requirements, medical surveillance for emergency responders and ERP review and updating procedures. The ERP also discusses emergency procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases and addresses emergency medical treatment.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The facility is committed to ensuring its operations are safe and in accordance with all RMP requirements. To ensure that appropriate changes are implemented as necessary to maintain and improve safety, ongoing PHAs, training, reviews and updates of operating procedures, audits, maintenance, and investigations will be conducted as required by the RMP.

The facility identifies ways to improve safety through a number of avenues, which include PHAs, audits, incident investigations, employee suggestions, and the preventative maintenance program. Recommended changes are evaluated for implementation to improve the overall safety of the facility. 

In addition, the facility continuously seeks and evaluates methods to improve the safety of its operations. Recommendations from audits, incident investigations, PHAs, equipment tests and inspections, and employee suggestions provide opportunities to enhance the safety of the facility. The Metallurgical Engineering and Inspection (ME&I) Department has well established inspection programs for piping, vessels and tanks that are consistent with American
